prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. The situation is about a couple where the author, who's in a relationship, pays all the bills because their girlfriend only works part-time. They had an incident where the author left their wallet and asked the girlfriend to pay for takeout, which she was upset about. Now the author is considering making her start paying some bills, even over this one incident.

First, I need to consider the dynamics of their financial situation. The author is paying all the rent and bills, which is common in relationships where one person earns more. But the girlfriend works part-time, so maybe she has limited income. The author is upset that she reacted negatively to paying $40 for takeout. The author feels that even though she can't cover all the bills, she should start contributing for the principle.

Now, is the author in the wrong? Well, making someone pay bills over a single incident might be a bit harsh. The girlfriend's reaction could be due to feeling taken for granted or maybe she's under financial stress herself. The author might be overreacting because one incident doesn't justify changing the entire financial arrangement. It's possible that the author hasn't communicated their expectations about shared responsibilities before, leading to the girlfriend's surprise and negative reaction. 

Also, considering the principle of fairness, even if the author pays most of the bills, the girlfriend might contribute in other ways, like household chores or emotional support. The author is now holding a single event to make her take on financial responsibilities, which might not be fair. It's important to have open communication and mutual agreement on how to split expenses based on each person's ability, rather than a reaction to a specific incident.

On the other hand, the author might feel that the girlfriend should contribute more, even if it's a small amount, to feel more involved. But pushing for it after one incident could be seen as holding a grudge. The key here is whether the author addressed the issue calmly and discussed the expectations, or if they're making a unilateral decision based on a single event. If the author hasn't had that conversation, they might be in the wrong by not considering the girlfriend's perspective and financial limitations.

So, putting it all together, the author might be in the wrong because they're reacting to a single incident without addressing the broader context and communication with their partner. Making someone pay bills over a $40 takeout without considering her part-time income and possible financial constraints isn't fair. The right approach would be to talk about how to share expenses moving forward rather than using one incident as leverage.
